data.name: ClinicalNeeds
data.value:
You should describe the clinical need that is the target of your device.

  • Example 1: write the common or technical name of the pathology, describe the main symptoms and if it is acute/chronic. “Down syndrome is a syndrome linked to various conditions, from lowered cognitive functions to increased risk of heart failure”.
  • Example 2: write the common or technical name of the handicap, describe if it is innate or caused by incidents or a consequence of a pathology: “Congenital club foot is a disease of newborn children that impairs the development of the lower limbs”.
  • Example 3: describe what is the patient need in terms of cost / improvement of life conditions / improvement of wellbeing: “Patients with high body temperature (fever) need to assess their body temperature every 1-4 hours in a quick and reliable manner”.

data.name: ConceptDescription
data.value:
You should describe the conceptual design selected in the Voting step.

Starting from the physics/chemistry/biology underlying the working principle, you should propose a first possible embodiment, providing sketches, diagrams, and/or other representation to communicate your idea. (If possible, please provide references to support your answer)

data.name: DesignForIsoTestingCompliance
data.value: With the help of your mentors, identify and design the necessary tests to demonstrate the compliance of your design with relevant ISO standards.

data.name: ExistingSolutions
data.value:
You should describe what are the devices or therapies on the market; if possible, list some pros and cons of the existing solutions.

  • Example: list medical, surgical or technical solutions available; define the criteria to choose amongst the have different options. Comment on residual side effects or contraindications that may be improved: ”Congenital club foot is usually treated by braces (mild cases) or surgery. Both solutions require long healing times and frequent specialistic follow up visits”.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_ElectronicAndFirmware_CommercialParts
data.value: Please insert here design and description of electronic parts of your device which you can buy from suppliers (e.g. microcontrollers, sensors, I/O boards, …). Describe all the libraries you use in your firmware.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_ElectronicAndFirmware_PrototypesAndFunctionalTrials
data.value:
Please insert here how to assemble step-by step the electronic part of your device, including instruction on how to upload the firmware.

Describe, also with videos and pictures how to verify your prototype.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_ElectronicAndFirmware_PurposelyDesignedParts
data.value:
Please insert here design and description of electronic parts of your device which you created from scratch (e.g. circuits, filters, routing ). You should include also CAD data as schematics and gerber files.

Describe your firmware using flow chart and comment your code.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_Hardware_CommercialParts
data.value: Please insert here design and description of mechanical parts of your device which you can buy from suppliers (e.g. box, valves, …)

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_Hardware_PrototypesAndFunctionalTrials
data.value:
Please insert here how to fabricate the purposely designed parts (e.g. gcode for 3D printers, CNC fabrication cycle with nc code) and describe step-by-step how to assemble all the components.

Describe, also with videos and pictures how to verify your prototype.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_Hardware_PurposelyDesignedParts
data.value: Please insert here design and description of mechanical parts of your device which you created from scratch (e.g. customized gears, purposely designed frames)

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_Software_ExistingSolutions
data.value: Please insert here free and open source libraries and programs you use in your device developed by other authors, without forgetting due credits.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_Software_PrototypesAndFunctionalTrials
data.value: Please describe here how to install you software (including specific requirements in terms of operating system, RAM, CPU, library dependencies.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_Software_PurposelyDesignedParts
data.value:
Please describe here your code using flowcharts and maps. If your code implements specific algorithms, please include comments in each key point.

You don’t have to cut and paste here your code, but save it in the proper folder in the repository.

data.name: GeneralProductDescription_SystemIntegration_PrototypesAndFunctionalTrials
data.value: Describe here how to integrate all the parts of your device, including wiring and connections.

data.name: InstructionsForFabricationOfPrototypes
data.value: Use this last section of WP3 to describe step by step how to fabricate and assemble the last version of your prototype: fill it once the part 1 and part 2 of WP3 can be considered stable.

data.name: IntendedUsers
data.value: You should describe who are the intended user of your medical device (e.g. physician, technicians, nurse, midwife, family member, self-use), and where the technology will be used (rural or urban settings, at home, hospital, …).

data.name: PhysicalPrinciples
data.value:
You should describe the most important operating physical principle of your medical device. Make sure to list every physical principal that you chose to comply to “Product requirements”.

  • Example: Contactless Infrared Thermometer is a device that measures the infrared radiation – a type of electromagnetic radiation below the visible spectrum of light - emitted by an object. The most basic design of infrared thermometers consists of a lens to focus the infrared thermal radiation onto a detector, which converts the radiant energy into an electric signal. This configuration facilitates temperature measurement from a distance, without the need for contact with the object to be measured.

data.name: ProductRequirements
data.value:
You should describe all the requirements to certain product. It is written to allow people to understand what a product should do. Typical components of a product requirements document are:

  • Functional requirements
    • Describe how your product will meet and solve the clinical need. Example: describe how the device interacts with the human body and why this interaction is beneficial: ”The syringe allows to deliver liquid substances, for example drugs, to the peripheral blood stream of the patient by piercing the vein walls without laceration”.
  • Usability requirements
    • Describe who will use the device and if they need special training. Example: define the professional profile of the end user: “A hip implant can be implanted in the patient only by a surgery team; all components of the surgery team are medical professional and at least one specialized orthopedic surgeon shall be responsible of the surgery”.
  • Safety requirements
    • Describe the main risks that your device may pose to the patient, to the users and bystanders and to the general environment. Propose solutions if you are aware of them. Example: evaluate electrical and mechanical safety of the device: “Hemodialysis machine is powered by electricity, there is a risk of electrocution of the patient and operator if it is not well insulated. In the same machine, the roller pump may hurt the operator hands if it is touched while it is rotating. Possible solutions include insulating the electrical connections and protecting the moving parts with covers or lids”.
  • Interaction requirements
    • Describe how the product should work with other systems.

data.name: PrototypesAndConsiderationsForSafetyAssessment
data.value: Describe the final implementation of the prototype of your medical device, with links to the repository. Put emphasis on how your device respect relevant standards.

data.name: QualityCriteria
data.value: Please indicate how your device can be evaluated according to specific criteria (both tests and parameters) for determining its proper implementation.

data.name: ResultsFromVitroOrVivo
data.value: If applicable and if available, please provide both protocols and results of in vitro and in vivo test of your medical device. In case on in vivo test, please provide also the ethical clearance from local ethical committee.

data.name: InfoForGeneralPublic
data.value: Use this section to provide descriptive materials for your project. Your audience is a general nontechnical public, interested in medical devices, as patients, healthcare providers, or investors. Videos, pictures, and/or infographics should be together with a catchy short description.

data.name: RealLifeUseOrSimulation
data.value: Describe in this section the use of your medical device in a real case scenario. Feed this part with videos, pictures, feedback from users, such as patients and healthcare providers.

data.name: PresentationForPress
data.value: Use this section to provide descriptive materials for your project to be used "as it is" (e.g. cut and paste) by media to spotlight your work. Pictures, slides, infographics and a "press release" are the most appropriate communication. The UBORA management group could ask you a illustrative materials to create a slider for the "featured projects" section.

data.name: ProductionDocumentation
data.value: Please provide documents necessary to produce the medical device, including e.g. working drawing, assembly drawings, gerber files, detailed instruction to compile eventual firmware and software...
